original_theorem:
If~$x$ is a rational number, then the sequence
$a_0, a_1, \ldots $
produced by the continued fraction procedure\index{continued fraction
procedure} terminates.

attempt_history.verified_code:
import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem terminates_of_rat (x : ℚ) : (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of (x : ℝ)).Terminates := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• x has a finite continued fraction representation x = $[b_0, b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ where bᵢ are integers and bᵢ > 0 for i > 0 [def_1].
• We assume m > 0 [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• x can be expressed as x = b₀ + 1 / $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ [l1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• The continued fraction representation x = $[b_0, b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ is the canonical one generated by the specified algorithm [def_1].
• We assume m > 0 [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The tail of the fraction, $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$, is not equal to 1 [l2].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• For the continued fraction representation x = $[b_0, b_1, \ldots, b_m]$, the quotients bᵢ are positive integers for i ∈ {1, ..., m} [def_1].
• The tail of the fraction, $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$, is not equal to 1 [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $[b_1, \ldots, b_m] > 1$ [l3].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• The continued fraction procedure computes a₀ = floor(x).
• x can be expressed as x = b₀ + 1 / $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ [l1].
• $[b_1, \ldots, b_m] > 1$ [l3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The first term produced by the continued fraction procedure is a₀ = b₀ [l4].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

lean_results.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• The continued fraction procedure computes the next value to process, x₁, as x₁ = 1 / (x - a₀).
• x can be expressed as x = b₀ + 1 / $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ [l1].
• The first term produced by the procedure is a₀ = b₀ [l4].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The next value to be processed by the procedure is x₁ = $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ [l5].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

lean_results.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
lean_results.error_msg: Skipped due to previous verification failure

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• x has a finite continued fraction representation x = $[b_0, b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ of length m+1 [def_1].
• The first step of the procedure on x = $[b_0, \ldots, b_m]$ produces a₀ = b₀ and a new rational number to process, x₁ = $[b_1, \ldots, b_m]$ [l4, l5].
• The continued fraction representation of x₁ has length m, which is one less than the length for x.
Therefore, we conclude:
• By repeatedly applying this step, the length of the continued fraction of the number being processed decreases by one at each step. Since the initial length m+1 is finite, the procedure must terminate after m+1 steps, having generated the finite sequence a₀, ..., aₘ [ts_1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
